snippet.textDisplay: @vulpixelful You are either an architect/dev or a domain specialist. You cannot be both, and there is no need for that even in a startup.
snippet.textOriginal: @vulpixelful You are either an architect/dev or a domain specialist. You cannot be both, and there is no need for that even in a startup.

snippet.textDisplay: @Vs Sm Again, in small startups that's usually the senior devs bothering the Product Owner and architecting it themselves. In smaller orgs with less headcount, senior devs aren't just implementers, we also are the architects
snippet.textOriginal: @Vs Sm Again, in small startups that's usually the senior devs bothering the Product Owner and architecting it themselves. In smaller orgs with less headcount, senior devs aren't just implementers, we also are the architects

snippet.textDisplay: @vulpixelful For a system design you need an architect, not a simple dev. In any case a domain specialist can be interviewed to get the specifics. You don't need to know everything, you need to learn how to ask right questions. This is what I do everyday as as dev, it's called translating business requirements to technical specifications.
snippet.textOriginal: @vulpixelful For a system design you need an architect, not a simple dev. In any case a domain specialist can be interviewed to get the specifics. You don't need to know everything, you need to learn how to ask right questions. This is what I do everyday as as dev, it's called translating business requirements to technical specifications.

snippet.textDisplay: Yes, I'm in a fintech startup too and this is true. In a bigger company, that may be "someone else's job" but not in a startup lol. The domain drives the system design.
snippet.textOriginal: Yes, I'm in a fintech startup too and this is true. In a bigger company, that may be "someone else's job" but not in a startup lol. The domain drives the system design.

snippet.textDisplay: That is indeed what is called domain knowledge. I work in educational software, and my coworkers with a background in education are the ones with domain knowledge, even though I have far more expertise in software.
snippet.textOriginal: That is indeed what is called domain knowledge. I work in educational software, and my coworkers with a background in education are the ones with domain knowledge, even though I have far more expertise in software.

snippet.textDisplay: @John Bennett Sorry, you are too wordy. Word diarrhea is not the best way of communication.
snippet.textOriginal: @John Bennett Sorry, you are too wordy. Word diarrhea is not the best way of communication.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Vs Sm apparently my message was not clear because you absolutely and totally misunderstand it. Lack of education? I graduated from CALTECH, one of the hardest colleges in the world. My job was hard because I chose one that is inherently hard. I did it because I enjoy the challenge. I got the job and
was given such limited direction because my boss trusted my knowledge and skill.
I guess you have been lucky and worked for a company with a real marketing department. Most companies so called market department is just a glorified sales team. They give limited and unreasonable "designs". The programmers have to sort it out and come up with the real design. Unfortunately too many programmers just do the minimum to get the code to work. In the end customers are frequently left with the choice between bad and horrible.

@John Bennett Exactly. When you don't bother getting a proper education, your life in programming is very hard like yours. When you have one, it's just yet another task you've been solving for years. My attitude is education. education and education. Your attitude is neither education, nor experience, otherwise you would know that any interface is paid for by a Marketing Department and not by talented UX/UI designers.
snippet.textOriginal: @John Bennett Exactly. When you don't bother getting a proper education, your life in programming is very hard like yours. When you have one, it's just yet another task you've been solving for years. My attitude is education. education and education. Your attitude is neither education, nor experience, otherwise you would know that any interface is paid for by a Marketing Department and not by talented UX/UI designers.

snippet.textDisplay: @Vs Sm if you are a coder, then fine. If you are what I would call a programmer, you need a lot more. At my last job, my assignment was "improve the accuracy of the handwriting recognizer". It was my job to figure out how to do this. It involved a combination of my knowledge, asking my colleagues, research and a whole lot of experimentation. Most programmers get more direction than this, but a lot of important details are left up to them. Your attitude is why every retail interface I have ever seen was somewhere between bad and truly horrible.
snippet.textOriginal: @Vs Sm if you are a coder, then fine. If you are what I would call a programmer, you need a lot more. At my last job, my assignment was "improve the accuracy of the handwriting recognizer". It was my job to figure out how to do this. It involved a combination of my knowledge, asking my colleagues, research and a whole lot of experimentation. Most programmers get more direction than this, but a lot of important details are left up to them. Your attitude is why every retail interface I have ever seen was somewhere between bad and truly horrible.

snippet.textDisplay: @JulianoGheller Before you get a specific role you have to get a proper education which let you get specialized in any field you want. The problem is that you don't have one and that's why cannot see a bigger picture.
snippet.textOriginal: @JulianoGheller Before you get a specific role you have to get a proper education which let you get specialized in any field you want. The problem is that you don't have one and that's why cannot see a bigger picture.

snippet.textDisplay: @Vs Sm I see it in another way. If your mindset is that you should only learn and execute things in your specific role, thats right (you can even call yourself a "Specialist"), but anyone who is curious enough to exceed your pre-determined attributions to contribute in as many ways possible (called a "Generalist"), is, in my opinion, way more valuable. Be whatever you want, but, notoriously, these individuals have a way higher chance to succeed just because they have a bigger range of skills

snippet.textDisplay: @Vs Sm exactly, it's not the technical things that differ, but the understanding of the priorities and the things that really would improve the product as a whole, that's why I used the "Junior with this knowledge > Senior without (for some cases) eu" argument. My point is that this Junior would have way more autonomy and direction of what needs to be done than the Senior, that would know HOW, but not what.

snippet.textDisplay: This is just a silly bias. How an input field or SQL query differ in real estate? I’ve been working in finance area for years and still have no idea what they talk about. For all your questions there is always a BA or someone from the business side.

snippet.textDisplay: I agree. It might be just a fintech thing. The knowledge of how the finance part works is a really important part in being able to even know where to start. It does cut both ways though into things like specific routines that do finance calculations, or audit reporting. I know in my company there's people who've done these for years and just know the entire range of possibilities in those specific areas
